ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Structure and magnetostriction of Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2) x alloys

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Faculty of Materials Science and Chemical Engineering, and Department of Physics

Affiliation.OrgName: School of Science, Shenyang Ligong University
School of Materials Science and Engineering, China Jiliang University

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Structural, magnetic and magnetostrictive properties of Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2) x (1.50 ≤ x ≤ 1.90) alloys have been investigated by means of X-ray diffraction (XRD), a vibrating sample magnetometer and a standard strain technique. XRD analysis shows the presence of single Laves phase with a cubic MgCu2-type structure for the high Nd content alloy around the composition of x = 1.80, which tends to be formed by curing at relatively low annealing temperature. The easy direction of magnetization at room temperature is observed toward <111> axis, accompanied by a rhombohedral distortion with a large spontaneous magnetostriction λ111. An optimized effect on the linear anisotropic magnetostriction, 360 ppm at 3 kOe, was observed for the high Nd content Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2)1.80 alloy, which can be attributed to its single Laves phase, the large λ111 (~1,520 ppm) of the MgCu2-type (Tb,Nd)(Fe,Co)2 phase and the good soft magnetic behaviors.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: The Laves phase REFe2 (RE = rare earth) compounds with cubic MgCu2-type structure, usually exhibiting giant room-temperature magnetostriction, have received much interest for application in sensors and actuators [1, 2]. For the purpose of actual application, besides the large magnetostriction, the low-cost and low magnetocrystalline anisotropy are requested. TbFe2 possesses the largest known magenetostriction at room temperature up to date, and it also exhibits high magnetocrystalline anisotropy [3]. Therefore, the anisotropy of TbFe2 should be lowered by introducing other RE such as Pr and Nd while still maintaining a large magenetostriction. NdFe2 has a large theoretical spontaneous magnetostriction (the coefficient λ111 up to about 2,000 ppm at 0 K) based on the calculation of the single-ion model [3]. Moreover, the sign of anisotropy constant K1 for NdFe2 is opposite to that of TbFe2. Thus, the low-cost light RE Nd-containing Laves phase compounds, the pseudobinary (Nd,Tb)Fe2, are the accepted anisotropy compensation system and have obtained the intense attentions in recent years [4]. However, the impurity of PuNi3-type phase usually presents especially for the Nd content larger than 20 at. %, because the radius of Nd3+ is large and the radius ratio of (R,Nd):Fe ion is too big to fit the ideal atomic radius ratio for Laves phase compound (1.225) [3, 5]. Recently, new works were performed in an attempt to synthesize the single Laves phase with a high Nd content, as an example, the interstitial/substituted elements B/Co were introduced into this system [6, 7]. In our previous work [7], the 20 at. % Co-doped (Nd,Tb)Fe2 alloys were prepared and it was found that the Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2)1.93 alloy, around the anisotropy compensation point, performs the good magnetoelastic properties. Otherwise, a trace of impurity was still observed in X-ray diffraction patterns. On the other hand, the heat-treated process and the composition ratio between light RE and transition metal (TM) sublattice are crucial for the formation of single Laves phase and the magnetostrictive properties [8, 9]. In the present work, we prepared the Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2) x alloys by tailoring the composition ratio x under different heat-treated processes. A single Laves phase was obtained, which presents good magnetoelastic properties, that is, the low magnetic anisotropy, the large λ111 (~1,520 ppm), the low coercivity iHc (~105 Oe) and the optimized effect on the linear anisotropic magnetostriction (360 ppm/3kOe).

Section1.Heading: Experimental details
Section1.Para: All polycrystalline samples of Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2) x alloys (1.50 ≤ x ≤ 1.90) were prepared by arc melting the appropriate constituent metals in a high-purity argon atmosphere [8]. The purities of the constituents are 99.9 wt% for Tb and Nd, and 99.8 wt% for Fe and Co, respectively. The melting was carried out three times to ensure homogenous mixing of the constituents. The arc-melted ingots were sealed in an evacuated quartz tube filled with high-purity argon and annealed between 670 and 720 °C for 5 days, and then furnace cooled to room temperature (RT). X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were recorded at RT with Cu Kα radiation in a D/max-γA diffractometer with a graphite crystal monochromator. In order to investigate the easy magnetization direction (EMD) and the spontaneous magnetostriction coefficient λ111, the high-precision XRD step scanning at RT was performed on powdered samples for the (440) peaks [10, 11]. Then, the effect of the Kα2 radiation was removed with a standard method and the XRD peaks were fitted using Jade 6.5 XRD analytical software (Materials Data, Inc., Livermore, CA, USA). Magnetization curves (M–H) at RT were measured using a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM). The two magnetostrictions, including the one due to the application of a parallel applied field H (denoted as λ||) and the one due to the use of a perpendicular H (denoted as λ⊥), were measured at RT using a metallic strain gauge with a gauge factor of 2.00 and a resistance of 120 Ω attached to the center of the samples and connected to a strain indicator.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
The powder XRD patterns for the Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2) x (1.50 ≤ x ≤ 1.90) alloys heat treated at 670 °C are shown in Fig. 1. It is found that the Nd-containing Laves phase with a MgCu2-type cubic structure can be obtained, indicating that the 20 at. % Co substitution for Fe tends to stabilize the formation of Laves phase in comparison with the (Tb,Nd)Fe2 Laves phase which can be synthesized only under high pressure [5]. As for the composition around x = 1.80, all the lines in XRD patterns can be indexed to the characteristics of the cubic MgCu2-type crystal structure with no evidence for any secondary phases (within the accuracy of XRD), which reveals the single (Tb,Nd)(Fe,Co)2 Laves phase being formed. The trace of the impurity, that is, the 1:3 phase with PuNi3-type structure for x > 1.85 and the RE phase for x < 1.75, is observed. These results reveal that diminishing the transition metal concentration of Fe/Co may restrain and benefit the formation of 1:3 and 1:2 phases, respectively, in accordance with the report by Yang [9]. To further study the effect of heat-treated process on the phases, in comparison, the samples were annealed at the higher temperature (T a), 700 and 720 °C, respectively. The powder XRD patterns, as an example for x = 1.80, are shown in Fig. 2. It is found that the impurity of 1:3 phase appears for T a = 700 °C, in particular, which becomes the main phase coexisting with the (Tb,Nd)(Fe,Co)2 Laves phase as a minority for T a = 720 °C. This result implies that the Nd-containing Laves phase is a meta-stable phase which may partially transform into 1:3 phase at higher T a, similar to the Pr-containing Laves phase [8], showing that T a is a crucial factor for the synthesis of single 1:2 phase with light RE. In addition, it is evident that 1:2 phase formed at 720 °C contains the higher Nd content. As shown in the inset of Fig. 2, X-ray reflection slightly shifts to lower Bragg angles with increasing T a, because of the increase of the lattice constant owing to the larger radius of Nd3+ ions.
Fig. 1
X-ray diffraction patterns of the Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2) x alloys heat treated at 670 °C ((h, k, l) of the Laves phase was indexed)
Fig. 2
X-ray diffraction patterns of the Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2)1.80 alloys heat treated at different temperatures. For clarity, the inset shows the patterns around 40°

It is known that spontaneous magnetostriction leads to crystal-structural distortion, such as the rhombohedral distortion for its EMD lying along <111> axis, of the Laves phase when it is cooled down below its Curie temperature T C [11, 12]. For the case of (Tb,Nd)(Fe,Co)2 Laves phase, T C was estimated to be around 650 K, much above RT [6, 7]. Thus, the EMD and magnetostriction coefficient can be obtained by X-ray crystallography study. In the present work, the (440) XRD line of the Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2) x alloys was step-scanned to study EMD and spontaneous magnetostriction. The profiles of the (440) line, deducted of K α2 with a standard method, are represented in Fig. 3. The splitting of the (440) line is clearly observed, indicating that the EMD is directed along the <111> axis and the alloy exists as a large rhombohedral distortion in the crystal structure. The magnetostriction coefficient λ111 of the Laves phase can be calculated using the following equation:

where θ 1, θ 2 are respectively diffraction angles of the split (440) lines [7, 13]. For this case, λ111 is calculated to be 1,180 ppm for x = 1.90, which gradually increases to 1,800 ppm (x = 1.50) with decreasing x. The composition dependence of λ111 is shown in Fig. 4a. It is noted that λ111 reaches a large value as 1,520 ppm for λ = 1.80, the high Nd content single Laves phase, meaning it a potential candidate for use.
Fig. 4
Composition dependence of a the magnetostriction coefficient λ111 and b the coercivity iHc of Laves phase in the Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2) x alloys

The magnetic field dependence of the magnetization at RT for the Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2) x alloys is shown in Fig. 5. It is seen that the magnetization is close to being saturation for all the alloys at the maximum available magnetic field of 20 kOe. The saturation magnetization M S decreases with decreasing the concentration of transition metal Fe/Co when 1.50 ≤ x ≤ 1.85, which can be ascribed to the increasing RE phase as indicated in XRD patterns (as shown in Fig. 1). The RE phase, the unreacted free Tb and/or Nd, presents the paramagnetic behavior due to its low Curie temperature below RT. Moreover, this magnetization behavior can be understood by the magnetic moment
$$ \mu $$
μ
of the Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2) x Laves phase, described as [7]

2
$$ \mu = 0.6\;\mu_{{\text{N} {\text{d}}}} - 0.4\;\mu_{{T{\text{b}}}} + x\mu_{{\text{Fe} /\text{Co} }} $$
μ = 0.6

It is known that in the rare-earth transition-metal (RE-TM) compounds, there are parallel (or antiparallel) alignments between the magnetic moments of neodymium (or terbium) and iron/cobalt atoms. Taking the magnetic moment of light rare-earth Nd and transition metal Fe/Co as positive, the magnetic moment of heavy rare-earth Tb appears to be negative. From this formula (2), it could be noted why the saturation magnetization M S increases with increasing x, if the influence of the small amount of impurities phase on the magnetization were neglected. As for the sample of x = 1.90, M S has a slightly lower value than that of x = 1.85, which can be attributed to the emergence of 1:3 phase (as shown in Fig. 1). The M S of (Tb,Nd)(Fe,Co)3 phase seems to be less than the M S of (Tb,Nd)(Fe,Co)2 in the alloy for the nominal composition of Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2)1.90, as an example, the saturation moment
$$ \mu $$
μ
at 0 K for TbFe3 and TbCo3 is 53.5 and 56.5 emu/g, respectively, which is less than that of TbFe2 (92.2 emu/g) and TbCo2 (114.8 emu/g) [14]. The magnetic hysteresis loops at RT were measured to determine the coercivity iHc (the loop curves at the maximum field of 20 kOe are not showed here), and the composition dependence of iHc is plotted in Fig. 4b. The coercivity iHc decreases markedly with increasing x when 1.50 ≤ x ≤ 1.80, while slightly increases with further increasing x and reaches a minimum value ~105 Oe near x = 1.80, which shows that the Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2)1.80 alloy has a good soft magnetic behavior in agreement with its most easily saturation in magnetization among all the samples (as shown in Fig. 5).

The magnetic field dependence of the linear anisotropic magnetostriction λ a (=λ||–λ⊥) for the Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2) x alloys is illustrated in Fig. 6. It is seen that λ a increases with increasing x when x ≤ 1.80 and decreases when x ≥ 1.85, and in particular, the Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2)1.80 alloy possesses a larger magnetostriction than that of others at a low magnetic field. This optimized effect on the low-field magnetostriction can be ascribed to its single Laves phase and the soft magnetic character in consistence with the saturation tendency for magnetization and the analysis of iHc. The XRD patterns (as shown in Fig. 1) confirmed that the second phase exists, wherein the RE phase for x < 1.75 and the 1:3 phase for x > 1.85. The magnetostriction is reduced owing to the hindrance of rotation of domains and motion of domain walls by the existing second phase and phase boundaries [15, 16]. For example, λ a for x = 1.50 presents the lowest value among these alloys even though it possesses the largest λ111 (~1,800 ppm). It is noted that the optimized magnetostriction, linear anisotropic magnetostriction λ a ~ 360 ppm at 3 kOe accompanied by the large λ111 (~1,520 ppm), is achieved for the high Nd content Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2)1.80 alloy with a single Laves phase.
Fig. 6
Magnetic field dependence of the linear anisotropic magnetostriction λ a (= λ||–λ⊥) for the Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2) x alloys

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In summary, the structure, magnetic properties and magnetostriction of the Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2) x (1.50 ≤ x ≤ 1.90) alloys have been investigated. XRD analysis shows that diminishing the transition metal concentration of Fe/Co and the proper heat-treated process may restrain and benefit the formation of PuNi3-type and MgCu2-type structure for the Nd-containing alloys, respectively. The high Nd content Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2)1.80 with a single Laves phase has been synthesized by arc melting following annealed at 670 °C. The EMD at RT is observed toward <111> axis, accompanied by a rhombohedral distortion with a large spontaneous magnetostriction λ111. An optimized effect on the linear anisotropic magnetostriction, 360 ppm at 3 kOe, was observed for the Tb0.4Nd0.6(Fe0.8Co0.2)1.80 alloy, which can be attributed to its single Laves phase, the large λ111 (~1,520 ppm) and the good soft magnetic behaviors.
